support.description: Content is actively maintained. Please report errors and inconsistencies

author_blurb.en: Translated for SuttaCentral by Bhikkhu Sujato, 2018. Dedicated to the public domain via Creative Commons Zero (CC0). You are encouraged to copy, reproduce, adapt, alter, or otherwise make use of this translation in any way you wish. Attribution is appreciated but not legally required.

segments.en: Numbered Discourses 7
6. The Undeclared Points
56. Tissa the Brahmā
So I have heard.

segments.pli: ekaṃ samayaṃ bhagavā rājagahe viharati gijjhakūṭe pabbate.
segments.en: At one time the Buddha was staying near Rājagaha, on the Vulture’s Peak Mountain.

segments.pli: Atha kho dve devatā abhikkantāya rattiyā abhikkantavaṇṇā kevalakappaṃ gijjhakūṭaṃ obhāsetvā yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkamiṃsu; upasaṅkamitvā bhagavantaṃ abhivādetvā ekamantaṃ aṭṭhaṃsu. Ekamantaṃ ṭhitā kho ekā devatā bhagavantaṃ etadavoca:
segments.en: Then, late at night, a glorious deity, lighting up the entire Vulture’s Peak, went up to the Buddha, bowed, stood to one side, and said to him,
“Sir, these nuns are freed!”
And another deity told the Buddha,
“Sir, these nuns are well freed without anything left over!”
This is what that deity said,
and the teacher approved.

segments.pli: Atha kho tā devatā “samanuñño satthā”ti bhagavantaṃ abhivādetvā padakkhiṇaṃ katvā tatthevantaradhāyiṃsu.
segments.en: Then that deity, knowing that the teacher approved, bowed and respectfully circled the Buddha, keeping him on his right, before vanishing right there.

segments.pli: Atha kho bhagavā tassā rattiyā accayena bhikkhū āmantesi:
segments.en: Then, when the night had passed, the Buddha told the mendicants all that had happened.

segments.pli: “imaṃ, bhikkhave, rattiṃ dve devatā abhikkantāya rattiyā abhikkantavaṇṇā kevalakappaṃ gijjhakūṭaṃ obhāsetvā yenāhaṃ tenupasaṅkamiṃsu; upasaṅkamitvā maṃ abhivādetvā ekamantaṃ aṭṭhaṃsu. Ekamantaṃ ṭhitā kho, bhikkhave, ekā devatā maṃ etadavoca:
Idaṃ vatvā maṃ abhivādetvā padakkhiṇaṃ katvā tatthevantaradhāyiṃsū”ti.
Tena kho pana samayena āyasmā mahāmoggallāno bhagavato avidūre nisinno hoti.
segments.en: Now, at that time Venerable Mahāmoggallāna was sitting not far from the Buddha.
He thought,
“Which gods know whether a person has anything left over or not?”

segments.pli: Tena kho pana samayena tisso nāma bhikkhu adhunākālaṅkato aññataraṃ brahmalokaṃ upapanno hoti.
segments.en: Now, at that time a monk called Tissa had recently passed away and been reborn in a Brahmā realm.
There they knew that
Tissa the Brahmā was very mighty and powerful.

segments.pli: Atha kho āyasmā mahāmoggallāno—seyyathāpi nāma balavā puriso samiñjitaṃ vā bāhaṃ pasāreyya, pasāritaṃ vā bāhaṃ samiñjeyya; evamevaṃ—gijjhakūṭe pabbate antarahito tasmiṃ brahmaloke pāturahosi.
segments.en: And then Venerable Mahāmoggallāna, as easily as a strong person would extend or contract their arm, vanished from the Vulture’s Peak and reappeared in that Brahmā realm.

segments.pli: Addasā kho tisso brahmā āyasmantaṃ mahāmoggallānaṃ dūratova āgacchantaṃ.
segments.en: Tissa saw Moggallāna coming off in the distance,
and said to him,
“Come, my good Moggallāna!
Welcome, my good Moggallāna!

segments.pli: Cirassaṃ kho, mārisa moggallāna, imaṃ pariyāyamakāsi, yadidaṃ idhāgamanāya.
segments.en: It’s been a long time since you took the opportunity to come here.
Sit, my good Moggallāna, this seat is for you.”

segments.pli: Nisīdi kho āyasmā mahāmoggallāno paññatte āsane.
segments.en: Moggallāna sat down on the seat spread out.

segments.pli: Tissopi kho brahmā āyasmantaṃ mahāmoggallānaṃ abhivādetvā ekamantaṃ nisīdi.
segments.en: Then Tissa bowed to Moggallāna and sat to one side.

segments.pli: Ekamantaṃ nisinnaṃ kho tissaṃ brahmānaṃ āyasmā mahāmoggallāno etadavoca:
segments.en: Moggallāna said to him,

segments.pli: “katamesānaṃ kho, tissa, devānaṃ evaṃ ñāṇaṃ hoti:
segments.en: “Which gods know whether a person has anything left over or not?”

segments.pli: “Brahmakāyikānaṃ kho, mārisa moggallāna, devānaṃ evaṃ ñāṇaṃ hoti:
segments.en: “The gods of Brahmā’s Host know this.”

segments.pli: “Sabbesaññeva kho, tissa, brahmakāyikānaṃ devānaṃ evaṃ ñāṇaṃ hoti:
segments.en: “But do all of them know this?”

segments.pli: “Na kho, mārisa moggallāna, sabbesaṃ brahmakāyikānaṃ devānaṃ evaṃ ñāṇaṃ hoti:
segments.en: “No, my good Moggallāna, not all of them.

segments.pli: Ye kho te, mārisa moggallāna, brahmakāyikā devā brahmena āyunā santuṭṭhā brahmena vaṇṇena brahmena sukhena brahmena yasena brahmena ādhipateyyena santuṭṭhā, te uttari nissaraṇaṃ yathābhūtaṃ nappajānanti.
segments.en: Those gods of Brahmā’s Host who are content with the lifespan of Brahmā, with the beauty, happiness, fame, and sovereignty of Brahmā, and who don’t truly understand any higher escape:
they don’t know this.

segments.pli: Ye ca kho te, mārisa moggallāna, brahmakāyikā devā brahmena āyunā asantuṭṭhā, brahmena vaṇṇena brahmena sukhena brahmena yasena brahmena ādhipateyyena asantuṭṭhā, te ca uttari nissaraṇaṃ yathābhūtaṃ pajānanti.
segments.en: But those gods of Brahmā’s Host who are not content with the lifespan of Brahmā, with the beauty, happiness, fame, and sovereignty of Brahmā, and who do truly understand a higher escape:
they do know this.

segments.pli: Idha, mārisa moggallāna, bhikkhu ubhatobhāgavimutto hoti.
segments.en: Take a mendicant who is freed both ways.
The gods know of them:
‘This venerable is freed both ways.

segments.pli: Yāvassa kāyo ṭhassati tāva naṃ dakkhanti devamanussā.
segments.en: As long as their body remains they will be seen by gods and humans.

segments.pli: Kāyassa bhedā na naṃ dakkhanti devamanussā’ti.
segments.en: But when their body breaks up gods and humans will see them no more.’

segments.pli: Evampi kho, mārisa moggallāna, tesaṃ devānaṃ ñāṇaṃ hoti:
segments.en: This too is how those gods know whether a person has anything left over or not.

segments.pli: Idha pana, mārisa moggallāna, bhikkhu paññāvimutto hoti.
segments.en: Take a mendicant who is freed by wisdom.
The gods know of them:
‘This venerable is freed by wisdom.

segments.pli: Yāvassa kāyo ṭhassati tāva naṃ dakkhanti devamanussā.
segments.en: As long as their body remains they will be seen by gods and humans.

segments.pli: Kāyassa bhedā na naṃ dakkhanti devamanussā’ti.
segments.en: But when their body breaks up gods and humans will see them no more.’

segments.pli: Evampi kho, mārisa moggallāna, tesaṃ devānaṃ ñāṇaṃ hoti:
segments.en: This too is how those gods know whether a person has anything left over or not.

segments.pli: Idha pana, mārisa moggallāna, bhikkhu kāyasakkhī hoti.
segments.en: Take a mendicant who is a personal witness.
The gods know of them:
‘This venerable is a personal witness.

segments.pli: Appeva nāma ayamāyasmā anulomikāni senāsanāni paṭisevamāno kalyāṇamitte bhajamāno indriyāni samannānayamāno—
segments.en: Hopefully this venerable will frequent appropriate lodgings, associate with good friends, and control their faculties.

segments.pli: yassatthāya kulaputtā sammadeva agārasmā anagāriyaṃ pabbajanti, tadanuttaraṃ—brahmacariyapariyosānaṃ diṭṭheva dhamme sayaṃ abhiññā sacchikatvā upasampajja vihareyyā’ti.
segments.en: Then they might realize the supreme culmination of the spiritual path in this very life, and live having achieved with their own insight the goal for which gentlemen rightly go forth from the lay life to homelessness.’

segments.pli: Evampi kho, mārisa moggallāna, tesaṃ devānaṃ ñāṇaṃ hoti:
segments.en: This too is how those gods know whether a person has anything left over or not.

segments.pli: Idha pana, mārisa moggallāna, bhikkhu diṭṭhippatto hoti … pe …
segments.en: Take a mendicant who is attained to view. …
freed by faith …
a follower of the teachings.
The gods know of them:
‘This venerable is a follower of the teachings.

segments.pli: Appeva nāma ayamāyasmā anulomikāni senāsanāni paṭisevamāno kalyāṇamitte bhajamāno indriyāni samannānayamāno—
segments.en: Hopefully this venerable will frequent appropriate lodgings, associate with good friends, and control their faculties.

segments.pli: yassatthāya kulaputtā sammadeva agārasmā anagāriyaṃ pabbajanti, tadanuttaraṃ—brahmacariyapariyosānaṃ diṭṭheva dhamme sayaṃ abhiññā sacchikatvā upasampajja vihareyyā’ti.
segments.en: Then they might realize the supreme culmination of the spiritual path in this very life, and live having achieved with their own insight the goal for which gentlemen rightly go forth from the lay life to homelessness.’

segments.pli: Evampi kho, mārisa moggallāna, tesaṃ devānaṃ ñāṇaṃ hoti:
segments.en: This too is how those gods know whether a person has anything left over or not.”

segments.pli: Atha kho āyasmā mahāmoggallāno tissassa brahmuno bhāsitaṃ abhinanditvā anumoditvā—seyyathāpi nāma balavā puriso samiñjitaṃ vā bāhaṃ pasāreyya, pasāritaṃ vā bāhaṃ samiñjeyya; evamevaṃ—brahmaloke antarahito gijjhakūṭe pabbate pāturahosi.
segments.en: Moggallāna approved and agreed with what Tissa the Brahmā said. Then, as easily as a strong person would extend or contract their arm, he vanished from the Brahmā realm and reappeared on the Vulture’s Peak.

segments.pli: Atha kho āyasmā mahāmoggallāno yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā bhagavantaṃ abhivādetvā ekamantaṃ nisīdi.
segments.en: Then Mahāmoggallāna went up to the Buddha, bowed, sat down to one side,

segments.pli: Ekamantaṃ nisinno kho āyasmā mahāmoggallāno yāvatako ahosi tissena brahmunā saddhiṃ kathāsallāpo taṃ sabbaṃ bhagavato ārocesi.
segments.en: and told him what had happened.

segments.pli: “Na hi pana te, moggallāna, tisso brahmā sattamaṃ animittavihāriṃ puggalaṃ deseti”.
segments.en: “But Moggallāna, Tissa the Brahmā didn’t teach the seventh person, the signless meditator.”
“Now is the time, Blessed One! Now is the time, Holy One!

segments.pli: Yaṃ bhagavā sattamaṃ animittavihāriṃ puggalaṃ deseyya. Bhagavato sutvā bhikkhū dhāressantī”ti.
segments.en: May the Buddha teach the seventh person, the signless meditator. The mendicants will listen and remember it.”

segments.pli: “Tena hi, moggallāna, suṇāhi, sādhukaṃ manasi karohi; bhāsissāmī”ti.
segments.en: “Well then, Moggallāna, listen and pay close attention, I will speak.”

segments.pli: “Evaṃ, bhante”ti kho āyasmā mahāmoggallāno bhagavato paccassosi.
segments.en: “Yes, sir,” Mahāmoggallāna replied.
The Buddha said this:

segments.pli: “Idha, moggallāna, bhikkhu sabbanimittānaṃ amanasikārā animittaṃ cetosamādhiṃ upasampajja viharati.
segments.en: “Moggallāna, take the case of a mendicant who, not focusing on any signs, enters and remains in the signless immersion of the heart.
The gods know of them:

segments.pli: ‘ayaṃ kho āyasmā sabbanimittānaṃ amanasikārā animittaṃ cetosamādhiṃ upasampajja viharati.
segments.en: ‘This venerable, not focusing on any signs, enters and remains in the signless immersion of the heart.

segments.pli: Appeva nāma ayamāyasmā anulomikāni senāsanāni paṭisevamāno kalyāṇamitte bhajamāno indriyāni samannānayamāno—
segments.en: Hopefully this venerable will frequent appropriate lodgings, associate with good friends, and control their faculties.

segments.pli: yassatthāya kulaputtā sammadeva agārasmā anagāriyaṃ pabbajanti, tadanuttaraṃ—brahmacariyapariyosānaṃ diṭṭheva dhamme sayaṃ abhiññā sacchikatvā upasampajja vihareyyā’ti.
segments.en: Then they might realize the supreme culmination of the spiritual path in this very life, and live having achieved with their own insight the goal for which gentlemen rightly go forth from the lay life to homelessness.’

segments.pli: Evaṃ kho, moggallāna, tesaṃ devānaṃ ñāṇaṃ hoti:
segments.en: This too is how those gods know whether a person has anything left over or not.”

suttaplex.blurb: Two gods come to the Buddha on Vulture’s Peak and declare that the nuns are liberated. Moggallāna interrogates one of the deities on what he means, and the Buddha adds further explanation.
